posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
The original build can be found here.

Created by Brian "Flameoftheabyss" Quah
Reformatted by HipMaestro & pals, 110912

Master Patch,

I suspect that you would be surprised at what path I have taken since leaving your foster care and my eventual employ with the Gutter Knives. While I value the hard lessons - both intentional and otherwise - that I learned at the hands of your many followers, I have since found another master. I always felt something viperous writhe in my stomach when you began anew your lessons in skulking, thieving, and murder with a new group of captive children. I could not see the twisting of life at your hands in my more tender years, but now, with ample experience and collected wisdom, I do. This new divine master goes by the name Chokra Broodslayer. When I first heard it, the name seemed to ring with meaning.

We were all your 'family,' were we not sir? I have grown very strong in the craft you had a hand in introducing to me. Very strong indeed. I come for you now, Patch. I will slink in the shadows alongside your best assassins and I will shatter your greatest champions face to face. I no longer fear either the dark or the light. I am not a cutpurse anymore dear Patch; I'm something new.

They call me devastation.

Death follows his path wherever he strides. All but the most wary and hardy fall before his might. Cunning and adept at fighting, it is he who uses the kukri with devastating effect, and inflicts tremendous pain unto his unwary victims.

Hail the Devastating Rogue. Unique, powerful, deadly. The rogue who specializes in raw power rather than in dexterity. This build makes an especially deadly warrior, and virtually anyone caught off-guard is almost certainly assured death. With a maximum of 84d6 sneak attack, high melee damage, and very likely devastating critical hits in his first attack maneuver, he is no laughing matter. Woe to the unwary who cross his path.

Rogue(36), Fighter(4), Elf, Chaotic Neutral (any alignment, per Hip 110912)

STR: 18 (28)
DEX: 16
CON: 12
WIS: 8
INT: 10

Background, Analysis and Comments by Author

Equipment
2 Kukri
Robes/Studded Leather

The uniqueness of this build is the fact that he can deal 84d6 sneak attack damage on his first attack phase, consisting of 3 attacks, if hasted. This is because of the 3 phases of combat per round of the NWN game engine, where attacks are divided into 3 parts, such that this character would get 3 attacks in the first phase (1st second), 2 attacks in the second phase (3rd second) and 2 attacks in the final phase (5th second).

Imagine the surprised look on your opponent's face when he sees many floating texts above his character, such as 'Sneak Attack," "Critical Hit," and the dreaded "Devastating Critical." Envision his extreme shock as his character suddenly drops dead!

Magical items and scrolls are great helpers, since he has a modified Use Magic Device check of 25, enabling him to use all magical items worth 100,000gp and below. Scrolls of Haste and Potions of Speed will prove especially invaluable to him, apart from various other scrolls, wands, and class-exclusive magical items, such as Boots of the Sun Soul, Sequencer Robes, and perhaps Monk robes, which should be easily obtainable for an epic character.

This character works well alone, but even better if he is in the company of melee warriors, as he will be able to fully show his destructive capabilities when flanking opponents with his sneak attacks. Also, in attempt to make up for his lack of Will and Fortitude, he has 20 Spellcraft ranks, which means he gets a +4 bonus to all saving throws against spellcasting.

Sure, he does have his shortcomings as well, but nothing that magical equipment can't handle.

Alternatively, this build could be used with scimitars or rapiers instead, and replacing the Exotic Weapon Proficiency with Knockdown. At a slight cost of attack, the Knockdown feat is gained. However, this is not recommended.

Note: There are both 20th and 40th level bic character files, but the 20th level character is not recommended for use as his powers are yet to be developed.

Devastating Rogue Advantages
Decent modified attack, deadly Sneak attacks, high regular melee damage, high critical threat (30% chance, 45% chance if keen), high critical damage, and Devastating Critical potential all in one.
Excellent stealth and detection.
Crippling Strike is easily inflicted
Is a decent fighter
Decent Reflex save

Devastating Rogue Disadvantages
Relatively low hit points (should obtain constitution-improving items such as Boots of Striding)
Relatively low AC for a rogue (should obtain Ring of Protection and Amulet of Natural Armor)
Mediocre Fortitude
Low Will save

Combat Tips
Buff up with Keen Edge Scroll and Potion of Speed (or acquire items which provide Haste, and Magical kukris with the Keen property)
Enter stealth mode
Sneak up on an opponent
Carve him like a Halloween pumpkin
If target miraculously survives, repeat as necessary =)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I do embrace the idea of a strength based, low intelligent ruffian, a deadly thug and lethal flanker.
Therefore, I had a look at this legacy build to see if there was something to learn from it.
The Sneak attacks of this build are impressive with 36 rogue levels and ISA X giving a SA bonus of 28d6!
There is also the strength based damage bonus to every hit.
Devastating critical with a DC of 39 and a threat range of 15-20 looks impressive.
However, there are some glaring weaknesses here too. The AB is too low with +36. The saves are low, and there is a 20% xp penalty during most of the career. There is WS, but no EWS, giving up +4 damage on every hit.
So I revamped the Devastating rogue and gave it much better AB, better saves, better damage per hit, added knockdown so you can land SA in toe to toe combat, improved the Dev crit DC, removed the xp penalty and added some hitpoints.
I took less rogue and had to cut down on the ISA feats to be able to do this. That means less skill points and less d6 in the Sneak damage. Less d6 SA may seem to defeat the purpose of the build, but the resulting build deals much more damage over all. The hit rate will be much higher with the improved AB. Each hit deals more regular damage with higher strength and EWS. You are able to land SA more often with better AB and Knockdown available.
You will also land critical hits more often now and the Dev crit DC is better, so you will "one-hit-kill" more often.
The OP recommends playing the character in Studded leather. You can use Full plate if you want, and even Full plate and Tower if you need the AC. When you want to use stealth, drink some Cat’s, wear some dexterity gear and downgrade the armor to Chain shirt/Scale mail or light armor.
SpoilerRogue(24), Fighter(6), Champion of Torm(10), Human DEX: 15 WIS: 8 CHA: 8 01: Rogue(1): Power Attack, Cleave 03: Rogue(2): Weapon Focus: Kukri, {Evasion} 05: Fighter(3) 07: Rogue(3): {Uncanny Dodge I} 09: Champion of Torm(1): Blind Fight 11: Champion of Torm(3): {Smite Evil} 13: Rogue(6) 15: Rogue(7): Iron Will 17: Rogue(9) 19: Rogue(11) 21: Champion of Torm(5): Epic Weapon Focus: Kukri 23: Rogue(13): Slippery Mind 25: Champion of Torm(8): Devastating Critical: Kukri 27: Champion of Torm(10): Great Strength II, Epic Weapon Specialization: Kukri, (STR=26) 29: Rogue(15) 31: Fighter(5) 33: Rogue(18): Great Strength IV, (STR=30) 35: Rogue(20) 37: Rogue(22) 39: Fighter(6): Great Strength VI, Epic Prowess, (STR=33) Saving Throws (Fortitude/Will/Reflex): 28/22/30 BAB: 27 AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only): 20/30 XP penalty: 0% Discipline 42(54), Hide 43(45), Move Silently 43(45), Search 21(21), Spellcraft 10(10), Spot 43(42), Tumble 40(42), UMD 36(35), remaining skillpoints 3 01: Hide(4), Move Silently(4), Search(4), Spot(4), Tumble(4), UMD(4), Save(12), 03: Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Search(2), Spot(2), Tumble(2), UMD(2), Save(7), 05: Discipline(1), Save(10), 07: Hide(4), Move Silently(4), Search(4), Spot(4), Tumble(4), Save(1), 09: Discipline(3), Spot(1), Save(4), 11: Discipline(1), Spot(1), Save(6), 13: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spot(1), UMD(5), Save(1), 15: Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Search(4), Spot(1), 17: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Search(1), Spot(1), Tumble(5), Save(4), 19: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spot(1), Save(10), 21: Discipline(7), Spot(1), Save(6), 23: Hide(3), Move Silently(3), Spot(1), Tumble(5), Save(4), 25: Discipline(1), Spot(1), Save(5), 27: Discipline(1), Spot(1), Save(7), 29: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spot(1), UMD(5), Save(1), 31: Discipline(4), Save(1), 33: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spot(2), UMD(5), 35: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spellcraft(5), Spot(1), Save(2), 37: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Spellcraft(5), Tumble(5), 39: Discipline(8),

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I like this improvement! I like the AB 43, which is 7 more than the previous build, meaning hitting way more often (and critting way more often)

Out of curiosity, were you ever tempted to try to go Rogue 23 / Fighter 16 / Shadowdancer 1 to try to access HiPS? :)

You'd lose 1d6 sneak attack to do that, and maybe 2-4 skill points (I think), and have to find space for Dodge and Mobility... Iron Will you could drop for Dodge, but you'd need to find one more feat... loathe to say this but one might have to drop 1 great strength, put Str to 17, Cons to 14 then there is an ugly floating stat point sitting around... anyway gonna stop thinking about it and play some NWN...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Don't get me wrong here, Mick, I do like this adaptation (what's not to like, after all?), but the first thing that popped into my mind was that it seemed to be a more stupid, more muscled mirror image of your very own Halfling Champion. And that, as is well-documented, is a build I love dearly (as well as being the first dexer I successfully played).

I mention it merely for compare and contrast purposes, not as criticism, because I heartily approve of the ethic of taking a sub-optimal premise (for want of a better term) and seeing what can be done with it.

Another successful re-tooling for the Stabby One!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote: ↑
Oct 15, 2019
I like this improvement! I like the AB 43, which is 7 more than the previous build, meaning hitting way more often (and critting way more often)

Out of curiosity, were you ever tempted to try to go Rogue 23 / Fighter 16 / Shadowdancer 1 to try to access HiPS? :)
Thank you Orion! 
As for Shadowdancer; no I was not tempted to use it here. This one can use stealth for tactical purposes and stand and fight like a Fighter. Flanking and KD will give opportunities for Sneak attacks, and the base damage is pretty good. So there is not much need for HIPS for crowd control and you don't depend on making repeated SA from stealth.
Another point is that the original is a straight up Fighter/Rogue with a limited number of tactics available, and I wanted to create a character that can do the same things, only better. 
I would normally also add lock picking and trap skills to a rogue build, and I often use SD too. But that would be a less brutal and more versatile build type with more feats, higher intelligence and more skills.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:

Oct 15, 2019
Don't get me wrong here, Mick, I do like this adaptation (what's not to like, after all?), but the first thing that popped into my mind was that it seemed to be a more stupid, more muscled mirror image of your very own Halfling Champion. And that, as is well-documented, is a build I love dearly (as well as being the first dexer I successfully played).

I mention it merely for compare and contrast purposes, not as criticism, because I heartily approve of the ethic of taking a sub-optimal premise (for want of a better term) and seeing what can be done with it.

Another successful re-tooling for the Stabby One!
This is definitely not the Halfling Champion.  The classes are the same and everything, but it stops there. 
Feel reassured, I see no critisism in your comparison Stag. And I know you have affection for my halfling.
And thank you for encouraging my attempts with these old builds.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I would consider IKD instead of Iron Will.  Knockdowns are a great way to generate sneak attacks.
